Promoter.comment: gcvRp is the primary transcription start site for the gcvR gene, since approximately 90% of its expression initiates from this promoter [Ghrist98].

Evidence-Code.common-name: Inferred by a human based on computational evidence
Evidence-Code.comment: Human inference. A curator or author inferred this assertion after review of one or more possible types of computational evidence such as sequence similarity, recognized motifs or consensus sequence, etc. When the inference was made by a computer in an automated fashion, use EV-AINF.

Automated inference. A computer inferred this assertion through one of many possible methods such as sequence similarity, recognized motifs or consensus sequence, etc. When a person made the inference from computational evidence, use EV-COMP-HINF.

Publication.title: Sigma70 promoters in Escherichia coli: specific transcription in dense regions of overlapping promoter-like signals.
Publication.author: Huerta AM
Collado-Vides J

Publication.title: Promoter characterization and constitutive expression of the Escherichia coli gcvR gene.
Publication.author: Ghrist AC
Stauffer GV

Evidence-Code.comment: The transcription start site is identified by primer extension.
A person inferred, or reviewed a computer inference of, promoter position relative to the -10 and -35 boxes.

IMP inferred from mutant phenotype.
The assertion was inferred from a mutant phenotype such as
  • Any gene mutation/knockout
  • Overexpression/ectopic expression of wild-type or mutant genes
  • Anti-sense experiments
  • RNA interference experiments
  • Specific protein inhibitors
  • Complementation

Comment: Inferences made from examining mutations or abnormal levels of only the product(s) of the gene of interest are covered by code EV-IMP (compare to code EV-IGI). Use this code for experiments that use antibodies or other specific inhibitors of RNA or protein activity, even though no gene may be mutated (the rationale is that EV-IMP is used where an abnormal situation prevails in a cell or organism).
